column1: Will the Supreme Court rule that any part of either North Carolina's or Maryland's congressional district maps is an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander?
column6: ['Society', 'US Politics', 'US Policy']

Expecting another punt.
Current jurisprudence says "to the victor belongs the spoils" so to speak. It is unlikely that we will see a complete reversal from the conservative majority.

Having made a ruling favoring Dems in Virginia (and stating that the state GOP did not have standing to appeal a lower court ruling), I think the conservative majority will conclude they have done "enough."
Many decisions to be handed down before the term end of term, evidence is strong towards gming.

Bethune-Hill gave us a taste of the justices' stances toward gerrymandering, despite the fact that the ruling was on standing grounds. Despite the fact that Gorsuch and Thomas joined the most liberal justices in the majority on this case, being arguably the two most conservative justices, they are unlikely to take an actual stance against gerrymandering (especially since a large majority of state legislative bodies that draw the districts are controlled by Republicans). But more tellingly, Roberts' and Breyer's dissent indicates some antagonism towards the anti-gerrymandering cause. Breyer may likely switch sides, but this case was a bit of a litmus test for Roberts for whom liberals are holding out hope that might deliver them a victory. So his reluctance puts a bit of a damper on the two cases in this question. The mix-up here and in 2 other recent also means there's a lot of uncertainty in the current leanings of the court. And interestingly, an identical decision in both cases would produce a victory apiece for Republicans and Democrats. It's a messy situation, but I'd put my money on a bit less than 50-50.
I think yesterday's SCOTUS ruling will satisfy Chief Justice Roberts that he has done enough on behalf of Dem's complaints about gerrymandering.
Omega hedging.
Good evidence of intent; applicable to both parties, plenty of room to limit remedies.

From Ballotpedi Supreme Court to issue 24 opinions by the end of June The Supreme Court has issued 45 decisions in the 69 cases for which it's heard oral arguments. The court's term ends at the end of June, so that means there are 24 cases still awaiting a ruling. By this date in 2018, the court had issued opinions in 42 of the 63 cases for which it heard oral arguments and had yet to issue decisions in 21 cases. Last year, the court added several additional, unplanned opinion release dates to account for the backlog. So far this year no additional dates have been announced - but stay tuned! On the one hand, conservative justices are likely to defer to the constitutional right of states to run elections; on the other hand the argument that gerrymandering violates certain rights granted in amendments survived in the lower courts and may hold water for scotus. Statistically, the fact that this question turns on two separate cases increases the odds of a yes answer.

Reiterating: Pretty sure a 5-4 majority will rule that the constitution mentions no role for the judiciary in the process, and politically they're satisfied that the status quo favors the GOP (only one seat would be at stake in Maryland).

There's a great deal of evidence, and I think it's likely they will acknowledge that and direct the lines to be redrawn. However, their ruling may be limited enough to leave an opening for Republicans to redraw the maps less egregiously while maintaining control.
The gerrymandering benefits the supreme court and their cohorts.

The Supreme Court overruled several lower court decisions finding gerrymandered districts unconstitutional. I still think it possible that the court could find Maryland's gerrymandering unconstitutional due to its unique issues while leaving North Carolina's in place.

Given the court is stacked with Republican Party hacks and given gerrymandering is integral to Republican political power, I find it very difficult to believe the court will rule against partisan gerrymandering. The court has ruled against racial gerrymandering but it has never ruled against partisan gerrymandering.
But the real question is can they get it redistricted in time for 2020?
SCOTUS has already deemed other areas as having been gerrymandered.

The Scotus had been stacked with Trump favoring, far right wing judges. I believe Republicans will fight hard to keep gerrymandered states like NC as they are, as this deviation from Constitutional law is politically advantageous to them.

Only moving up from 20 to 25%. I'm still pretty sure Roberts will join a 5-4 majority insisting that the U.S. Constitution explicitly lays the responsibility on state legislatures. They don't want to see the courts getting involved; they don't want any more cases coming to them; the status quo benefits the GOP (Maryland's Dem gerrymander would only make a difference to one seat). I moved the odds up marginally only because of the strong voices coming from lower courts. I still think, if Roberts will rule against the GOP on anything this term, it will be the citizenship question on the census.
The either makes me feel like they are slightly higher than not to overturn one of the maps especially after what happened in 2018 with pennsylvania
Some indications in this direction

Coming up to 65% on the basis that the case below establishes a threshold for gerrymandering. Federal district court strikes down Ohio congressional district plan as unconstitutional partisan gerrymander A three-judge panel of the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio ruled unanimously that Ohio's congressional district plan constitutes an illegal partisan gerrymander. The court held that the plan, enacted in 2011 by a Republican legislature and governor, violates the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of Democrats. The panel, comprised of Judges Karen Moore (appointed by Democrat Bill Clinton), Timothy Black (appointed by Democrat Barack Obama), and Michael Watson (appointed by Republican George W. Bush), enjoined the state from conducting any future congressional elections under the 2011 plan. The court ordered the state to enact a remedial plan by June 14, 2019. Should the state fail to meet this deadline, or should the state's remedial plan fail to meet the approval of the court, the court may appoint a special master to draft a remedial plan. This marks the second time in as many weeks that federal courts have struck down district plans as unconstitutional partisan gerrymanders. On April 25, 2019, a three-judge panel of the United District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan ruled unanimously that 34 Michigan congressional and state legislative districts had been subject to unconstitutional partisan gerrymandering, violating Democrats' First Amendment associational rights. The court also found that 27 of the 34 challenged districts violated the Democrats' First and Fourteenth Amendment rights by diluting the impact of their votes. The phrase partisan gerrymandering refers to the practice of drawing electoral district maps with the intention of favoring one political party over another. In contrast with racial gerrymandering, on which issue the Supreme Court of the United States has made rulings in the past affirming that such practices violate federal law, the high court has not, to date, made a ruling establishing clear precedent on the question of partisan gerrymandering. Two partisan gerrymandering cases—Rucho v. Common Cause and Benisek v. Lamone—are pending before the high court this term. Rulings are expected by the end of June.

The Supreme Court sill has never found a gerrymandered district map unconstitutional. However, the district courts are finding these maps to be unconstitutional more and more frequently. Normally, the district courts are hesitant to rule on a issue that is before the Supreme Court. Therefore, the fact that they did should put at least some pressure on the justices to find gerrymandering unconstitutional.
On paper the Supreme Court appears to lean towards the right however Kavanaugh has proven to be a real wild card. I do not expect to see a ruling of all maps but a few may very well be agreed upon

While proportional representation is not constitutionally guaranteed, the facts presented to the SCOTUS in the North Carolina case cleanly presents the more narrow issue of whether there are any constitutional constraints on a minority state legislature redistricting their state so as to effectively entrench that minority party's political power and diminish the aggregate value of the votes of those who voted for an opposition party. On the merits, and under principles of equal protection and free speech, the SCOTUS has routinely found State sanctioned political discrimination to be inappropriate and constitutionally protected in analogous circumstances. The more liberal justices will almost certainly vote to overturn these politically cynical power-grabs, that deliberately aim to (and effectively do) minimize the effective voting power of an entire political group. That said, mired factual questions about what a state legislature's "predominant purpose" is from year to year in redistricting maps threatens to place judges and juries far too often in a position of constant review of potentially political questions, which conservative jurists are ordinarily hesitant to indulge.
Time to clarify issue.

SCOTUS looks at this issue as a political issue, not a judicial issue. It is to be resolved by politicians, not jurists.

The question of whether the consideration of race as a factor in drawing electoral maps is a thorny one and something the justices really want to avoid ruling on its constitutionality. The court's liberal wing on one side seems to be keen on the idea that a gerrymandered electoral map should be reviewed by the courts on a case-to-case basis. On the other hand, the conservative bloc is weary of the thought of gerrymandering cases haunting the court without any visible end to it. The conservatives has many times hinted that although racial gerrymandering is an unfortunate thing, but it is not for the courts to decide this question. No feasible and objective standard to determine just how much racial factor in a gerrymandered electoral map must be there for it to be considered unconstitutional, can be found. It lies in the end on the current center of the court - CJ John Roberts and in my estimation, he will either side with the conservatives to end the racial gerrymandering cases from being taken up by courts once and for all or duck the question again for another day. Either which, that would resolve to NO.
Kavanaugh sounded like he might think about it seriously.

Updating again...J. Kavanaugh and J. Gorsuch keep coming out on opposite sides of cases. Granted, none of them have had the impact that this case would, but I think it shows that J. Kavanaugh might be a bit more moderate than we would've guessed. Not much of an upward movement, but 2% seems about right.

I am of the opinion that SCOTUS hand picked these two cases because works out to the advantage of each of the two parties. I think that was purposeful and indicates that ROberts and Ginsberg want to find a manageable standard to reduce political polarity in races. In Rucho v. Common Cause, the court will hear the appeal of a district court ruling that found that North Carolina's congressional map constituted an illegal partisan gerrymander favoring Republicans. The SCOTUS will also decide whether the plaintiffs, Common Cause and the League of Women Voters of North Carolina, have standing to press their partisan gerrymandering claims and whether such claims can be decided by the courts. In Lamone v. Benisek, the court will hear the appeal of another district court ruling that found that Maryland’s congressional map constituted an illegal partisan gerrymander favoring Democrats. The SCOTUS will also decide whether the district court panel articulated unmanageable legal claims, erred in how it viewed evidence, and abused its discretion in issuing an injunction against further use of the maps. In both cases, the district courts ruled that the maps in question should not be used for the 2020 congressional elections, which will be the last cycle before the redistricting that occurs after the upcoming census.
Oral arguments were heard today. I skimmed the transcripts and read some of the commentary.

After reading the oral argument transcripts, I'm sticking with my March 16 forecast for 8 of the Justices: Ginsburg, Sotomayor, Breyer, and Kagan will vote for finding the maps unconstitutional; Thomas, Gorsuch, Alito, and Thomas will vote to allow them.

I saw a comment mentioning that the language is important for this forecast. Even if the gerrymandering done in these states is a bit below the belt, that does not necessarily make it unconstitutional. It is important to research further before making a more drastic prediction about what the Court will decide.
the key is the word unconstitutional. the court may easily find the gerrymander repugnant but within the constitutional law.

Supreme Court to hear two cases next week on partisan gerrymandering Although we’re only about a year away from the next census in 2020, disputes over how redistricting was implemented after the 2010 census continue to be debated by the courts. On Tuesday, the U.S. Supreme Court is scheduled to hear oral argument in two cases concerning what constitutes an illegal partisan gerrymander. Gerrymandering refers to the practice of drawing electoral district lines to favor one political party, individual, or constituency over another. In Rucho v. Common Cause, the court will hear the appeal of a district court ruling that found that North Carolina's congressional map constituted an illegal partisan gerrymander favoring Republicans. The SCOTUS will also decide whether the plaintiffs, Common Cause and the League of Women Voters of North Carolina, have standing to press their partisan gerrymandering claims and whether such claims can be decided by the courts. In Lamone v. Benisek, the court will hear the appeal of another district court ruling that found that Maryland’s congressional map constituted an illegal partisan gerrymander favoring Democrats. The SCOTUS will also decide whether the district court panel articulated unmanageable legal claims, erred in how it viewed evidence, and abused its discretion in issuing an injunction against further use of the maps. In both cases, the district courts ruled that the maps in question should not be used for the 2020 congressional elections, which will be the last cycle before the redistricting that occurs after the upcoming census.

The likely relevant questions in these cases will follow similar lines as Vieth v. Jubelirer, 541 U.S. 267 (2004). First, is partisan gerrymandering a non-justiciable issue because of the political question doctrine? Second, should the 14th or the 1st Amendment control if the issue of political gerrymandering is in fact something the Court can address?

Most likely a 5-4 decision that the U.S. Constitution clearly puts the responsibility in the hands of state legislatures. As a political calculus, the conservatives may also consider the (likely) one-seat advantage for Democrats in the Maryland delegation a small price to pay to continue to allow GOP gerrymandering in states such as NC, WI and TX.

I've approached this question as a series of questions: First, will the Court decide that plaintiffs in either case have standing? In Maryland, plaintiffs are residents of a single district whereas in N.C., plaintiffs are "voters at large." I believe the SCOTUS will agree that plaintiffs in at least one of the cases have standing.

States' rights would suggest that they remain in control of districting, because there cannot be sauce for the goose (Maryland democrats) on this one which is not sauce for the gander (old republican urban districts). At a party level both have something to lose but the imbalance now showing up between voting patterns and electoral results will have to be addressed soon, and the republicans may prefer this while they have the House and the Supreme Court . However, that assumes a cool set of heads on the Hill. The answer would be a separate commission, but that would over-ride states, and also cast doubt over the legitimacy of some state governments. Can't see the turkeys voting for Christmas on this one.

Since the court is dominated by Republicans, I think the majority opinion will favor the Republican party, and I think that opinion will hold that there is no individual right to be free of gerrymandering.

With Kennedy gone, I think there will be a 5-4 majority that will say that constitution says it's entirely up to state legislatures, so the federal courts should not interfere. In fact, there are conservatives who argue that state referenda that try to take redistricting away from state legislatures and give them to independent commissions are unconstitutional. However, I can see roughly a 10% chance that Roberts might blink at Maryland - it's a Dem gerrymander and it's pretty extreme.

I am not confident in how this stands as a strictly Constitutional matter; strong case to be made for local control of elections and State's Rights. Also, not entirely confident of SCOTUS remaining non-partisan.
Gerrymandering is on the way out - there are too many objective ways to create districts and all parties are going to be forced to live with one.

Kennedy was the justice most in favor of a standard that could be used to measure and eliminate partisan gerrymandering. With him gone it seems unlikely that his replacement will rule against the practice.

The Ruling will be 5-4, s usual. The Supreme court no longer decides cases on the merits, but rather on political considerations. Reapportionment will cause those states ot lose Republican congresspersons...
With a right leaning court, it is hard to imagine they will make any voting rights easier for the Democrats.
Long-term, this is not a partisan issue, so perhaps the Court will rule on it in that context.
